_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Duke Energy Progress' Roxboro Steam Electric Plant is a coal-fired, electric power generating facility located in Semora, North Carolina. The plant uses anhydrous ammonia in Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) systems to control nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions. The SCR systems are designed to inject ammonia vapor into the boiler flue gas and then pass the ammonia/flue gas mixture through a catalyst. The catalyst causes a reaction that reduces NOx (pollutant) in the flue gas, converting NOx into nitrogen gas and water. The Roxboro Plant stores the ammonia in three (3) 65,450-gallon anhydrous ammonia storage tanks. The anhydrous ammonia in the storage tanks is liquefied under pressure. These tanks are limited to a maximum fill volume of 55,600 gallons (85%). The Risk Management Plan addresses the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia used in the SCR system.



Roxboro Plant has established an Accidental Release Prevention program for the ammonia system that complies with the regulatory requirements of both OSHA (Process Safety Management, PSM, 29CFR1910.119) and EPA (Risk Management Program, 40CFR68). In addition, for responding to emergencies the plant has an Emergency Action Plan and an Emergency Response Plan that complies with all regulatory programs, including OSHA Emergency Response Planning requirements (29 CFR 1910.120(q) and 1910.38). The Emergency Response Plan has been coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



The SCR systems were placed in service between 2001 and 2005. There is no accident history. To further ensure a safe process, Process Hazard Analysis was conducted for commissioning of each of the SCR systems. Opportunities to improve process safety stemming from the first PHA, and continuing from each PHA since, were identified and implemented, including equipping the system with interlocks and excess flow valves and establishing emergency shutdown procedures. As well, the ammonia storage tanks were located in a dike desig

ned to contain 110% of the entire inventory of a single tank. 



To further comply with regulatory mandates, a Worst Case Scenario (WCS) and an alternate scenario have been developed and modeled for this 5-year update of the RMP. The RMP Comp model (a model accepted by the EPA) was used for the dispersion modeling.  The WCS is defined by the EPA as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to the endpoint.  The scenario used for this analysis was a release in which the maximum quantity in the largest vessel completely released over a 10-minute period. This is extremely unlikely due to tank design and construction.  Notwithstanding, the model predicts an off-site impact.



The Alternate Release Scenario (ARS) was the case where transfer hose rupture in which the total quantity in the truck is completely released over a 22-minute period. Notwithstanding, the model predicts 0.3-mile impact.



The Roxboro Steam Electric Plant, striving to become better in its PSM safety program and employee participation, continues to involve employees through quarterly engagement meetings.
